commentBody: The GamePlay link is broken ‚Ä¶ again!
THERESNOTWOWAYSABOUTIT: Wordplay was offline‚Ä¶ should someone be sent to there SINBIN?

Guess I‚Äôm old and a geek since I know what UHF (and VHF, AM, FM, etc.) stand for.

I paused to think about how many people have never even heard of those terms!

Sam Corbin says she doesn‚Äôt like puns
At least, only high-quality ones
Her work must be painful
If she‚Äôs disdainful
For in the comments there are (usually) tons

I sped through Monday's puzzle with a time of 6:02 and no lookups, so imagine my surprise when the difficulty spiked for me and today's took me 18 minutes to solve!
I didn't get the theme until halfway through, and by that time I had messed myself up with LETiT instead of LETAT, Ready instead of RARIN (which I think was clued strangely, shouldn't it have had an apostrophe?), dMS instead of IMS, and sPit instead of OPEN.
That was unusually difficult for a Tuesday.

This page's URL should be https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/05/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2026-01-06.html -- but this has a 2025 after "-puzzle". I know, ya don't write checks any more, so you have to put last year's date somewhere...
What a weirdly maddening Tuesday!

It took me longer to find this column than it did to solve the puzzle ü§£ Anyhoo, this was a tight theme. NO TWO WAYS ABOUT IT, this seemed tougher than a typical Tuesday (at least for me). I‚Äôm not even sure why I struggled once the answers finally filled in. I‚Äôm old enough that I even knew what the U was in UHF ü§£ It just took me 4 minutes longer than my average for a Tuesday. All that being said, I enjoyed it. NO CAP.

I appreciated this theme, finally, and it was clever and well executed, but I had a rather bizarre solving experience in that I seemed to be constantly dooked by all the long answers and having trouble parsing them until they were almost all done‚Äîseems like I solved almost exclusively with downs. Even the downs ATLOWEBB and ONIONSKIN gave me pause. It didn‚Äôt help I had a few bad first guesses on downs also, like DAMN before DUMB, IRAN before OMAN, things like that‚Äîunusual for a Tuesday for me. Ultimately I finished all the long themers before the revealer, and the revealer last, so was done before I had time to appreciate the theme. But I do like it.
A few nits‚ÄîI feel like the clue for RARIN ought to have some signal for informality or contraction, and the revealer is informal as well‚ÄîI know it needed to be symmetrical, but it seems like properly it needs to be ‚Äúthere ARE no two ways about it‚Äù‚Äîto the point where I actually tried there‚ÄôR no two ways‚Ä¶‚Äù before getting the S in SARA (which I didn‚Äôt have originally). I‚Äôm not saying break or don‚Äôt use the revealer over it‚ÄîI assume some people do say this incorrectly or informally‚Äîit just bugs me, and I feel like the clue should have added ‚Äúcolloquially‚Äù or something to admit it was grammatically incorrect. Did that bother anyone else?
In any case, other than that the weird solve seems more on me than the constructor, and this was a decent Tuesday and kudos.

I remember when Chicagoland got its first UHF TV station. My dad hooked up a separate antenna, and an adapter box for the TV (which only tuned channels 2-13). We called it the "channel 26 antenna", though before long there were other UHF stations on the air.

It is official. I completed the archive today. 

Total of 11,453 puzzles. Streak at 1847.

I‚Äôm still not doing Pips.

I had a lovely time doing this puzzle. Didn't get the NO-IT-ON trick until I was staring at the completed clues' circled elements. I still keep reading it as 'notion' backwards.

Lots of excellent fill. Knew L-Dopa from the great Robin Williams film "Awakenings". Glad to see SINBIN -- elbows up, my fellow CDNs! It's getting pretty crazy in the neighbourhood. I used to use pink ONIONSKIN for my carbon copies; onionskins used to be functionally equivalent to carbons.

This was fun! Thanks to Mr. Coulter.

This is easily the hardest Tuesday I've ever played.  Naticks all over the place.  

Lots of obscure proper nouns like ADOLFO, SARA, IMAN, lots of extremely awkwardly phrased words that still don't make complete sense to me like AT A LOW EBB and every theme clue.  A lot of really nichey knowledge like GESSO, ONIONSKIN.

This took me as long as a Thursday or Friday but without any satisfying lightbulb moments, not a good puzzle at all IMO.

I guess so. More like no two ways AROUND it. Seeing NOTION spelled backwards three times caused me to think that was part of the theme, but it wasn't. Wrong notion. 

I'm hoping to see NO CAP again on Thursday. Keep the pattern going. 

L-Dopa made me think of "Awakenings" based on the Oliver Sacks book, made into an interesting movie, but it seemed to promote El-Dopa as a miraculous cure that reversed the effects of Parkinson's -- that's how I remember it, anyway -- when in reality it's not that simple or that completely effective. The movie came out in 1990, and I couldn't help but see echoes of Ron Howard's 1985 "Cocoon" where residents of a Florida rest home, including the incomparable Hume Cronyn, become raucously rejuvenated by using the pool in a nearby abandoned vacation home, the pool also being used by aliens to store and incubate their cocoons, which gave the water its magic powers.

no...it...on...

nah.

solid tuesday otherwise.

I initially has SPIT for 25D, which made me very confused about 24A.  And not knowing LDOPA or ADOLFO didn't help matters either. since I couldn't get enough letters in place to guess at 24A.  

Got there eventually, albeit almost 3 1/2 minutes over my average for a Tuesday...

Sigh. It seems that yet again, the (app/web devs and/or editors ?) can't be bothered proofing their link to the column. From the 404 Not Found page, I searched for "crossword", to find that the URL of the column is apparently https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/05/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-01-06.html If only someone at the NYT was aware that 2025 is SO last year! As for the puzzle itself? NO TWO WAYS ABOUT IT - yawn.

I had Tendon for 33D, which clearly was wrong not being plural, so for a bit I thought, huh, rebus on Tuesday? Fortunately I had just finished The Book of Eels, and there was a snippet in there about the author's grandmother dowsing for water. (With a tenuous speculation that the ideomotor action of dowsing, like the unconscious movement of a ouija board piece, might be somehow similar to an eel inexplicably starting its migration back to the Sargasso Sea-- idk, I think he just wanted to tell that story lol). Anyway, once I got DOWSE in there, SINEWS was easy.

A good Wednesday morning puzzle. 

Thanks

The theme answers all have a similar "feel" to them, of someone struggling against the tide, so to speak.  Is there an intended connection between that sense and NO TWO WAYS ABOUT IT, or am I making it all up in my head?  The connection doesn't feel airtight to me, but it also doesn't feel like a complete coincidence, either.  I can't tell if I'm overthinking this.

This was a tough-ish Tuesday. Took me longer than my average, and I believe it was because the phrases weren't obvious immediately, because it wasn't that difficult as far as the other answers. Trying to figure out what the circles were there for was also part of it, and I did fall for sPit before OPEN.

I do think that this was a bit easier for older solvers, with the Star Trek answers, David Bowie's supermodel wife, and one of the two most famous Osmonds, although by number of spaces it could have been either, but if one had any crosses placed, it eliminated one. I was fortunate enough to have taken art history, which I did as an excuse to get off-base housing, and so the art-related answers weren't hard to get.

I'm definitely old enough to remember that our new-at-the-time TV set had two rotary channel switches, and that the main switch had 2-13 plus a U which made the second switch active so you could select your UHF channel.

Anyway, despite the minor struggle, I thought it a good challenge for a Tuesday. Thanks, Paul.

I did not like this puzzle. RARIN? LDOPA? Two star trek clues? UTERI? GESSO? The theme answers were the most disappointing, I love a good pun but was underwhelmed. I‚Äôm getting cranky, need to put myself to bed‚Ä¶

Not only am I back from beautiful, subtropical Madeira in freezing cold, snowy Warsaw but to add in5ult to injury, I was presented with this puzzle...

What was that?! Not a Tuesday, in my opinion. I was utterly confused by the theme, and I found the fill full of unknowns (ADOLFO, ROMO, GESSO, SARA to name a few). I needed lookups, and I actually checked the puzzle in the end when I got the "So close" pop-up and just couldn't be bothered anymore with this unpleasant grid.

I'm not saying the constructor is unskilled, mind you. It's just that I personally disliked the result of his efforts, and the decision of the editors to run it on Tuesday.

Of course this probably means the veterans loved this, and I'll probably find a slew of "Delightful! I love, love, love the theme and fill!!!" comments below ü§£

PS. How hard is it to properly link the column in the app? I know the NYT IT team is not the best out there, to put it mildly, but c'mon...

Add me to the chorus of people who found this strangely difficult for a Tuesday, much more of a Thursday. But the difficulty really isn‚Äôt a sticking point ‚Äî a ‚Äúhard‚Äù Tuesday is still a relatively painless solve. There was just this uncanny aspect to the phrases‚Ä¶worded differently than I‚Äôd expect them to be, never coming together in a satisfying way. Different wavelengths!

Wait‚Ä¶ how long was I asleep? What day is this? I think the editors may have forgotten to reset more than the year on today‚Äôs calendar.

I like a challenge, but this wasn‚Äôt an enjoyable one for me. ADOLFO/L-DOPA, clunky phrases like THERE‚ÄôS NO TWO and AT A LOW EBB, the NO-IT-ON gag that took too long to figure out and wasn‚Äôt worth the payoff. 

Plus, RARIN? That word alone almost convinced me that the circles indicated rebuses. Something to indicate a truncation was really needed there.

Meh. Maybe I‚Äôm just grumpy because of all the time travel.
I really enjoyed it.  Hope I'm not a minority of one.

Had to close out of the app a couple of times to make sure I didn‚Äôt accidentally click on an older Thursday or Friday puzzle. Sheesh! So many far too tricky clues for a Tuesday. Parkinson‚Äôs drugs? Amniocentesis? C‚Äômon now!

Unlike so many others, I have no problem with rarin.  It was a gimme for me.  I have heard, and used, the phrase many times in my life.  I have never heard it with the unabbreviated raring.  It's always been rarin to go, so I don't think the clue needed anything to indicate the dropped g.

Always pleasantly surprised when a Tuesday makes me sweat a little. 

The more difficult than "normal" Tuesday is much, much preferred to the Friday or Saturday I can finish in "Tuesday" time.

NO CAP again, already! The OED's first citation of "no cap" is from a tweet posted on 12 June. 2011, by @King_Me7--how's that for specific?: "Just seen a pic on fb of my ex and his recent gf she look like wanda Sykes no cap."* But, as slang, "to cap" goes back at least a hundred years before that, with various meanings including "to brag," "to insult," "to lie," and "to swindle (in a con game," all overlapping: https://greensdictofslang.com/entry/iw5rwii https://greensdictofslang.com/entry/lpnjaia ** *unless @King_Me7 meant that the young lady looked like "wanda small-"w," no caps(s) Sykes." **I've noticed that hyperlinks to Green's Dictionary of Slang--an excellent resource--do not include the word itself--is that to allow one to cite it without incurring the wrath of censorious ratites? *** *** Fred and Ginger walk their dogs; George saw it all: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TjJm-bSd6RU&list=RDTjJm-bSd6RU&start_radio=1

A few misdirects--Marie before DONNY, SINBox before SINBIN and spit before OPEN. 
Always a pleasure to see UHURA and LEVAR. 
And I had to work to get the theme.

Thanks for a nicely Toughened Up Tuesday, Paul and editors.

This puzzle had several clues I knew because of my dad, who had a tv business. I knew UHF due to the antennas I helped him install. He liked to ‚Äúwater witch‚Äù and I loved watching him do it. Alas, he also developed Parkinson‚Äôs, so L-dopa popped into mind quickly, although I knew about it from various science courses. I miss my dad. He had a saying for every situation and so I often recall his words.

Hey, when the theme finally hit me, when I finally saw it, I inwardly shrieked a huge ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù, inwardly stood up and bowed deeply.  This was an ultra aha, in the cream-of-the-crop peloton of ahas for me.

How word-playful is that ‚Äì taking THERE‚ÄôS NO TWO WAYS ABOUT IT literally?  That, for me, is top-class fun. That, for me, is a happy button that doesn‚Äôt get pushed very often.

When that happens, I don‚Äôt care about any nits in the box that may come my way. I am won over, smitten, highly grateful.  

Then I read his notes where he mentioned his ‚Äúlatest novel‚Äù.  So I looked up his name; there are several writers with the same name, and I wondered which one he was.  

I looked at his first NYT puzzle notes, and there was the answer (in case you too were wondering): ‚ÄúI'm a retired Biology professor ... setting a world record for most novels never published (35 and counting.)‚Äù

Hey, Y'all! So, "sin bin" made it into Green's Dictionary of Slang! The entry says "orig. US sporting," but all of the citations are British and Australian, and most are in the context of rugby, or "football." "Sin bin" is also used in Australia for "a van or car used primarily for sex." Near the end of 2025 I felt there was an increasing/inordinate number of puzzles where so many people commented that it was too easy/difficult for the day it ran. (Today is another.)

So it got me thinking - how often actually (based on solve times) does a week of Mon. ~ Sat. puzzles increase in difficulty daily?

For me in 2025, the answer was: 7

I.e., for me in 2025, 45 of 52 weeks had a puzzle that ran on the "wrong" day. 

A week of progressively difficult puzzles is the exception, not the norm. I think if more of us accepted this, there'd be fewer complaints about wrong difficulty for the day.

The almost daily comments on degree of difficulty for a day of the week reminds me of when I first started teaching chemistry.  I gave a whole lot of quizzes, trying to keep student from getting too far behind.

At first it was *very* hard for me to determine how easy or difficult a quiz would be.  I'd give one that I thought would have a 70 average and it would get an 85 average.  Or I'd think I was giving a quiz with a 85 average, and it'd turn out to be sub 60.

I have no idea if this has any connection to the puzzle difficulty/day of the week problem, but I'd be curious to know if the constructor and/or the editors are aware that a puzzle is going to be way easy or way hard when they actually create it.

3 nits to pick:

1. Yes, L-dopa is a drug to treat Parkinson's, but it is short for levodopa, and the clue does not indicate an abbreviation

@SP Looking at usage in published books, the usage trends are kind of interesting. The phrase appears to have arisen in print in 1827, using the prescriptively incorrect ‚Äúthere‚Äôs‚Äù variant. Starting around 1845, the prescriptively correct ‚Äúthere are‚Äù variant started to become popular, with the more common variant shifting between the two until the 1880s, when the ‚Äúthere are‚Äù variant became dominant and has remained so until at least the year with the most recently available data (2022). However, the ‚Äúthere‚Äôs‚Äù variant has become more common again since the turn of the millennium, with both variants now apparently in relatively common use, albeit with ‚Äúthere are‚Äù still leading slightly. (A third variant using ‚Äúthere is‚Äù has always had very marginal usage, according to the data.) https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=there%E2%80%99s+no+two+ways+about+it%252Cthere+is+no+two+ways+about+it%252Cthere+are+no+two+ways+about+it&year_start=1825&year_end=2022&corpus=en&smoothing=3&case_insensitive=true
